Expectation1: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation1: A recently updated standard will apply to the upcoming release, and evidence of conformity is required
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They try to keep moral values in mind during everyday routines
Story:
I sat at my desk, the hum of the office fading as I stared at the email from management. The new safety standard had just been updated, and our team was expected to release the product next week. As the lead engineer, it was my responsibility to ensure every box was checked, every test documented. But the evidence for full compliance wasn’t there yet; we needed more time, more data. My manager’s message was clear: “We need to show conformity for the release. Find a way.”

I felt the weight of my Christian values pressing on me. Honesty, integrity—these weren’t just words I heard on Sundays, but principles I tried to live by every day. Could I sign off on the documentation, knowing we hadn’t met every requirement? The pressure to deliver was immense, and my team was counting on me. But so was my conscience. I closed my eyes, wrestling with the expectations of my profession and the demands of my faith, caught between the need to comply and the call to be truthful.
